Authors:
Patrick J. Krug, Jann Elizabeth Vendetti, A. Rodriguez,
Jennifer N Retana, Yayoi M. Hirano , Cynthia D Trowbridge
Title:
Integrative species delimitation in photosynthetic sea slugs
reveals twenty candidate species in three nominal taxa studied for drug
discovery, plastid symbiosis or biological control
Keywords:
Barcoding Caulerpa Candidate species Elysia Heterobranchia
Kahalalides
Abstract:
DNA barcoding can highlight taxa in which conventional
taxonomy underestimates species richness, 32 identifying mitochondrial
lineages that may correspond to unrecognized species. However, key
assump- 33 tions of barcoding remain untested for many groups of
soft-bodied marine invertebrates with poorly 34 resolved taxonomy. Here,
we applied an integrative approach for species delimitation to
herbivorous 35 sea slugs in clade Sacoglossa, in which unrecognized
diversity may complicate studies of drug discovery, 36 plastid
endosymbiosis, and biological control. Using the mitochondrial barcoding
COI gene and the 37 nuclear histone 3 gene, we tested the hypothesis
that three widely distributed ‘species’ each comprised 38 a complex of
independently evolving lineages. Morphological and reproductive
characters were then 39 used to evaluate whether each lineage was
distinguishable as a candidate species. The ‘circumtropical’ 40 Elysia
ornata comprised a Caribbean species and four Indo-Pacific candidate
species that are potential 41 sources of kahalalides, anti-cancer
compounds. The ‘monotypic’ and highly photosynthetic Plakobran- 42 chus
ocellatus, used for over 60 years to study chloroplast symbiosis,
comprised 10 candidate species. 43 Finally, six candidate species were
distinguished in the Elysia tomentosa complex, including potential bio-
44 logical control agents for invasive green algae (Caulerpa spp.). We
show that a candidate species approach 45 developed for vertebrates
effectively categorizes cryptic diversity in marine invertebrates, and
that inte- 46 grating threshold COI distances with non-molecular
character data can delimit species even when com- 47 mon assumptions of
DNA barcoding are violated.
